topics.title: Fight Club: scheduling conflict to resolve issues early
topics.summary: Megan describes a weekly 30-minute standing meeting with product, engineering, and design leadership dedicated to surfacing and resolving conflicts early, preventing avoidance and building stronger relationships.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Megan Cook, her role leading Jira product, her background, and what the episode will cover (multi-product strategy, competition, play, buy-in, remote PM, failure stories).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Teal (job search platform) and Sprig (product insights platform).

topics.title: Why play and psychological safety matter
topics.summary: Megan explains how ambiguity and remote-era changes reduced openness and increased fear, and how a mindset talk reframed play as the opposite of fear—motivating a deliberate push for psychological safety to unlock bolder ideas.

topics.title: Peer feedback groups to normalize early drafts
topics.summary: She shares a tactic: small biweekly peer feedback groups where PMs bring rough work (strategies, experiments, experiences) to build trust, model good feedback, and make critique routine rather than scary.

topics.title: Twice-yearly onsite: craft, strategy, and failure stories
topics.summary: Megan describes bringing PMs together every six months for relationship-building, strategy alignment, craft workshops, and senior leaders sharing failures to normalize learning and risk-taking.

topics.title: Signals of safety decline and the $10 priorities game
topics.summary: They discuss when formality and reluctance to speak up can emerge (around ~15 PMs), plus a practical alignment tool: allocating “$10” across priorities to reveal time spend, overload, and mismatches with goals.

topics.title: Remote work at Atlassian: connection and intentionality
topics.summary: Megan explains Atlassian’s shift to remote during COVID, the “Team Anywhere” philosophy, and research-backed practices like intentional in-person gatherings a few times per year to boost connection and productivity.

topics.title: Remote execution: deep work blocks and async status
topics.summary: She shares tactics to avoid meeting overload: synchronized deep-work blocks for leaders, problem-solving meetings over status updates, and strong documentation via tools like Atlas and Confluence.

topics.title: Async video as a new collaboration primitive
topics.summary: To handle time zones, Megan describes using quick audio/video recordings (including for 1:1s and document context), noting how this approach influenced Atlassian’s acquisition of Loom.

topics.title: Getting buy-in: treat it as a journey
topics.summary: Megan outlines how buy-in comes from early stakeholder partnership, iterative check-ins, and focusing on the underlying problem rather than a single “perfect proposal,” using a Jira templates/platform example.

topics.title: Show hypotheses, not certainty; meeting setup matters
topics.summary: She advises explicitly separating facts from hypotheses, inviting critique to build credibility, and structuring exec meetings with clear asks, narrative framing, and command of data; includes an acquisition-vs-build example.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Vanta (security and compliance automation).

topics.title: Fighting the good fight: investing in CSAT improvements
topics.summary: Megan explains how Jira drove a major usability/CSAT push by grounding the case in customer feedback and business impact, coordinating across dependent platform teams with low-cost “shepherd” support, showing (not telling) via designs and user pain, and starting small to build momentum (e.g., dark mode and other quality-of-life wins).

topics.title: Atlassian’s multi-product success: setup and early history
topics.summary: Lenny tees up Atlassian’s rare ability to build ~15 product lines; Megan begins answering by referencing Jira’s origins as a humble bug tracker and how it has adapted through major industry shifts (discussion continues beyond the provided excerpt).
